prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: The case law has limited restrictive covenants to a reasonable geographical area.[1] Where an employer's business is established over a specific area or territory, the courts may find that a covenant should have been limited to that same area or territory. Even then, the restraint must be unreasonable in the circumstances. For example, an employer may not be able to prevent a former employee from competing in the employer's territory where a large urban area is involved and there are many competitors within the area.[2] However, in M.E.P. Environmental Products Ltd. v. Hi Performance Coatings Co.,[3] the Manitoba Court of Queen's Bench found that a confidentiality agreement that prevented former employees from actively soliciting the Manitoba employer's customers and suppliers in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and northwestern Ontario for a period of five years was not unreasonable. The agreement did not prevent the former employees from competing in a huge environmental products and services market, of which the employer had developed its market share over 25 years.[4]
The courts have also made it clear that there must be some geographic limitation specified. For example in Sherwood Dash Inc. v. Woodview Products Inc.,[5] the court held:

The spatial feature of the restrictive covenant is particularly problematic. There is no spatial limitation, and Messrs. Nguyen and Burton are essentially disqualified from working in a field in which they have acquired skills and knowledge. The information and training provided by an employer to an employee that do not involve trade secrets are beyond the reach of a restrictive covenant: Maguire v. Northland Drug, supra; Leng v. Andrews, [1909] 1 Ch. 763. In my view, the non-competition clause in the immediate case goes too far in protecting the proprietary interests of Sherwood and is not reasonable as between the parties nor is it reasonable in terms of the public interest.

In Trapeze Software Inc. v. Bryans,[6] an interlocutory injunction was denied since there was not a strong prima facie case that the non-competition and non-solicitation clauses were enforceable. The clauses prohibited former employees from working anywhere in the world where the employer marketed its products or services for one year following the end of their employment. The court found that this was too broad and therefore unreasonable.[7]

In Craig v. CEO Global Network Inc.,[8] CEO Global was in the business of providing professional consulting services to corporate executives through group mentoring, expert speaker programs and executive coaching. Wilson carried on that business previously with a competitor, TEC Canada, where he worked with the Plaintiff Craig. After Wilson established CEO Global, he invited Craig to join. Craig became the executive vice-president of CEO Global. The Consulting Agreement he signed provided for a one-year term that would automatically renew on its anniversary date subject to rights of early termination. Part way through the second term, CEO Global provided sixty days' notice to Craig of termination of the Consulting Agreement. CEO Global agreed to pay Craig six months' compensation additional to the sixty days' notice, consistent with its interpretation of the Consulting Agreement's provision for termination without cause. CEO Global paid Craig the first month of notice, but then did not pay the second month of notice or the six months of additional compensation. CEO Global's lawyer notified Craig that CEO Global was discharged from making any further payments to him because it discovered that he had breached the non-competition provision contained in the Consulting Agreement, thereby entitling CEO Global it to terminate the Consulting Agreement for cause.[9]

On March 29, 2019, Craig produced to CEO Global a confidential client and prospective client list that he had downloaded from the CEO Global computer system four days after he was provided with notice of termination but before the expiry of the sixty-day notice period. He also produced a copy of CEO Global's Strategic Plan created on February 4, 2011 that he had retained. At the start of the closing submissions at trial, CEO Global amended its statement of defence to plead that it was entitled to terminate the Consulting Agreement with cause by reason of Craig's breach of the confidentiality provision of the Consulting Agreement and his breach of the duty of honesty and good faith that he owed to CEO Global in the performance of the contract. CEO Global did not tender any evidence of any harm, or detriment of any nature, resulting from Craig having had confidential documents in his possession in the more than seven years that had passed since termination. The trial judge concluded that CEO Global failed to establish just cause for its termination of the Consulting Agreement. The Plaintiff was entitled to judgment against CEO Global of $150,899, plus pre-judgment interest.[10]

CEO Global contended that it was justified in terminating Craig for cause on the basis that he materially breached the Non-Competition Provision. The burden of establishing that the Non-Competition Provision is lawful and enforceable is on the party seeking its enforcement. The general principle applied in most common law jurisdictions is that “non-competition clauses in employment contracts are void” because a non-competition provision in an employment contract is a restraint of trade, and restraints of trade are contrary to public policy considerations because they interfere with individual liberty of action. The Supreme Court has stated that restrictive covenants are enforceable only when they are reasonable. The onus is on the party seeking to enforce the restrictive covenant to establish that its terms are reasonable. The Supreme Court of Canada has drawn a distinction between restrictive covenants contained in commercial contracts and in contracts pertaining to employment, noting that different considerations are pertinent to each. In particular, in the employment setting there may be an imbalance in power between the parties to the employment contract. The reasonableness test for assessment of a restrictive covenant has been found to be applicable to independent contractor relationships as to employer-employee relationships.[11]

The trial judge was of the view that there were factors that rendered the Non-Competition Provision unreasonable. CEO Global had not established that the geographic scope of the Non-Competition Provision, being “the geographic area of Canada and the United States in which the Client carries on business”, was reasonable. The reasonableness of a restrictive covenant must take into consideration the “extent of the activity sought to be prohibited and the extent of the temporal and spatial scope of the prohibition”. CEO Global sought to restrain the business of Craig as an independent contractor in the entirety of Canada and the United States for a year. There must be a rational basis for the breadth of its reach in order to be reasonable, and that had not been established. The trial judge concluded that the geographic scope of the restrictive covenant was unreasonable because its scope was broader than necessary to protect the interests of CEO Global.[12]

(3d) 180 (S.C.J.), the court held that, in the circumstances, a specific geographic limitation was not necessary with respect to a non-solicitation clause, as the definition of “clients” would accomplish that task.
